docs.snippet: In Italian Town, It's Time to Pelt the Neighbors  Ivrea, in northern Italy, hosts a three-day orange-throwing festival each year. The event is said to stem from medieval times, when the local population was incited to rebellion by a woman who kill...
docs.lead_paragraph: In Italian Town, It's Time to Pelt the Neighbors Ivrea, in northern Italy, hosts a three-day orange-throwing festival each year. The event is said to stem from medieval times, when the local population was incited to rebellion by a woman who killed a nobleman. PAGE A4 Riding the Oscar Bandwagon Newspapers and magazines are dedicating their Web sites to all things Oscar in advance of next Sunday's Academy Awards ceremony, with videos, blogs, polls, predictions and contests. BUSINESS DAY, PAGE C1 No. 3 in a Stoppard Trilogy Ben Brantley reviews ''Salvage'' (with Brian F. O'Byrne, below), the finale of Tom Stoppard's ''Coast of Utopia'' cycle. THE ARTS, PAGE E1 Rice Works to Hold Together Plan to Restart Mideast Talks Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice, shuttling between Jerusalem and the occupied West Bank, said she planned to continue to push a peace initiative between Israel and the Palestinian Authority president despite his agreement in principle to form a unity government between his Fatah faction and Hamas, which the United States and Israel view as a terrorist organization. PAGE A8 Airlines and Liquor Laws After a deadly wreck caused by a drunken driver just off a plane, New Mexico has told airlines they must have liquor licenses to sell alcohol on flights to or from the state. Three airlines have stopped doing so. PAGE A10 Accused Officer Speaks Out A police officer, accused of covering up for her husband after another officer was shot, says she is not a traitor to her badge and did not know about the shooting. PAGE B1
docs.section_name: Front Page; New York and Region

docs.snippet: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43rd Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.c...
docs.lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43rd Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com. COMEDY Hasbrouck Heights Damon Wayans, stand-up. Thursday at 7:30 p.m. $40. Bananas Comedy Club, 283 Route 17 South. (201) 727-1090. FILM Bloomfield ''The Mad Adventures of Rabbi Jacob,'' directed by Gérard Oury; in French with English subtitles. Feb. 25 at 3 p.m. Free. Temple Ner Tamid, 939 Broad Street. (973) 338-1500. Jersey City ''By Popular Demand,'' screenings of ''Back to the Future,'' ''Gone With the Wind'' and ''Casablanca.'' Friday and Feb. 24. $4 and $6. Landmark Loew's Jersey Theater, 54 Journal Square. (201) 798-6055. Mahwah ''Tanguedia Callejera,'' documentary by Marta Bautis. Wednesday at 1 p.m. Free. Sharp Theater, 505 Ramapo Valley Road. (201) 684-7844. Morristown ''Aspects of Love,'' film series: ''Love, Actually,'' directed by Richard Curtis. Thursday at 6:30 p.m. Free. The Morristown and Morris Township Library, 1 Miller Road. (973) 538-6161. New Brunswick ''Pee Wee's Big Adventure,'' directed by Tim Burton. Feb. 24 at 11 p.m. $5. Crossroads Theater, 7 Livingston Avenue. (732) 545-8100. New Brunswick The New Jersey Film Festival, Spring 2007; schedule and information: njfilmfest.com. Through April 15. $4 to $10. New Jersey Media Arts Center, 72 Lipman Drive. (732) 932-8482. Trenton Oscar-nominated short films, presented by the Trenton Film Society. Feb. 24 at 7 p.m. $12 and $15. The New Jersey State Museum, 225 West State Street. (609) 292-6464. West Orange ''Annual West Orange Classic Film Festival,'' screenings of films including ''Bonnie and Clyde'' and ''Casablanca''; some screenings are followed by discussions of the films. Schedule: westorangeartscouncil.org. Through March 15. $6 and $7. AMC Theater, Essex Green Shopping Center, (973) 324-9100. FOR CHILDREN Camden Dan Zanes and Friends, family concert. Feb. 25 at 1 and 4 p.m. $12 and $16. Walter K. Gordon Theater, Camden Center for the Arts, Rutgers University, Third and Pearl streets. (856) 225-2700. New Brunswick ''Clifford the Big Red Dog Live,'' family performance. Monday at 1 and 4 p.m. $20 to $25. State Theater, 15 Livingston Avenue. (732) 246-7469. MUSIC AND DANCE Camden Gordon Theater Jazz Festival: Robert Glasper Trio. Feb. 24 at 8 p.m. $12 and $16. Walter K. Gordon Theater, Camden Center for the Arts, Rutgers University, Third and Pearl streets. (856) 225-2700. East Rutherford Chris Tomlin, singer-songwriter, with Louie Giglio. Feb. 18 at 7:30 p.m. $25 to $35. Continental Airlines Arena, 50 Route 120. (201) 507-8900. Englewood Mozart's ''Marriage of Figaro,'' by the Bulgarian State Opera. Friday at 8 p.m. $25 to $50. The Trinity Irish Dance Company and Different Drums of Ireland. Feb. 24 at 8 p.m. $28 to $65. Bergen Performing Arts Center, 30 North Van Brunt Street. (201) 227-1030. Hamilton ''Fat Tuesday'' celebration, with dancing, food and music by Snapperhead Zydeco. Tuesday, 6 to 10 p.m. $35. Grounds for Sculpture, 18 Fairgrounds Road. (609) 586-0616. Holbrook Lil' Cliff and the Cliffhangers, blues. Feb. 25 at 2 p.m. Free. Sachem Public Library, 150 Holbrook Library. (631) 588-5024. Mahwah Hawthorne Symphony, works by Charlie Parker, Beethoven and Verdi. Feb. 18 at 3 p.m. $12 to $22. Conference Choir of the A.M.E. Zion Church, gospel. Feb. 24 at 8 p.m. $12 to $24. Sharp Theater, 505 Ramapo Valley Road. (201) 684-7844. Morristown Liza DiSavino and A. J. Bodnar, with the Homegrown String Band, folk. Friday at 8:30 p.m. $7. Minstrel Coffeehouse, Morristown Unitarian Fellowship, 21 Normandy Heights Road. (973) 335-9489. Morristown Three Mo' Tenors, opera, jazz and blues. Friday at 8 p.m. $32 to $47. The Community Theater, 100 South Street. (973) 539-8008. New Brunswick Edward Simon, pianist and composer, and his Ensemble Venezuela; with the Rutgers Jazz Ensemble. Tuesday at 8 p.m. Free. Nicholas Music Center, Rutgers University, 85 George Street. (732) 932-7511. Newark Academy of St. Martin in the Fields; Sir Neville Marriner, conductor; Jonathan Biss, pianist; works by Stravinsky, Mozart and Beethoven. Feb. 18 at 3 p.m. $24 to $88. B. B. King. Thursday at 8 p.m. $35 to $95. The New Jersey Symphony Orchestra; Peter Oundjian, conductor; Steven Isserlis, cellist; works by Bryars, Elgar and Beethoven. Friday through Feb. 25. $22 to $77. New Jersey Performing Arts Center, 1 Center Street. (888) 466-5722. Paramus ''Summer and Smoke,'' drama by Tennessee Williams. Through Feb. 25. $7 and $10. Bergen Community College, 400 Paramus Road. (201) 447-7428. Pleasantville The O'Jays, soul. Feb. 24 at 8 p.m. $40 to $55. Jacob Burns Film Center, 364 Manville Road. (914) 773-7663. Princeton Christopher O'Riley, pianist, and the Bad Plus, jazz. Friday at 8 p.m. $16 to $38. Spring student dance festival, choreographed by Princeton faculty and others. Friday through Feb. 25. $15. Dan Zanes, family concert. Feb. 24 at 10:30 a.m. and 1:30 p.m. $18. Natalie MacMaster, with David Bromberg, folk and dance. Feb. 24 at 8 p.m. $35 and $38. McCarter Theater Center, 91 University Place. (609) 258-2787. Rahway James Gibbs III, jazz trumpeter. Friday at 8 p.m. $14 and $16. Arts Guild of Rahway, 1670 Irving Street. (732) 381-7511. Red Bank David Cassidy. Feb. 24 at 8 p.m. $25 to $100. Hootie and the Blowfish. Feb. 25 at 7:30 p.m. $30 to $100. Count Basie Theater, 99 Monmouth Street. (732) 842-9000. Red Bank Ching-Yun Hu, pianist. Feb. 24 at 8 p.m. $20. Two River Theater, 21 Bridge Avenue. (732) 345-1400. South Orange ''See How They Run,'' comedy by Phillip King; presented by Seton Hall University's Arts Council. Friday through March 2. $8 to $15. South Orange Performing Arts Center, 1 Sopac Way. (973) 313-2787. Teaneck Steady Rollin' Bob Margolin with Nappy Brown, blues. Thursday at 9 p.m. $20. Jupiter One, All Parallels and Hello Eden, rock. Friday at 9 p.m. $10. Popa Chubby, music of Jimi Hendrix. Feb. 24 at 9 p.m. $20. Mexicali Blues Cafe, 1409 Queen Anne Road. (201) 833-0011. Trenton The New Jersey Symphony Orchestra; Peter Oundjian, conductor; Steven Isserlis, cellist; works by Bryars, Elgar and Beethoven. Feb. 24 at 8 p.m. $22 to $77. Patriots Theater at the War Memorial, Memorial Drive. (609) 984-8400. Trenton ''Keeping the Faith,'' gospel music and spirituals by Princeton Pro Musica and the Bright Hope Baptist Church Celestial Choir. Feb. 25 at 4 p.m. $20. Trinity Cathedral, 801 West State Street. (609) 683-5122. Upper Saddle River ''Basically Baroque,'' by All Seasons Chamber Players. Feb. 25 at 2 p.m. Free. Upper Saddle River Library, 245 Lake Street. (201) 327-2583. Watchung Kings Road Band, swing. Friday at 8 p.m. $15. Watchung Arts Center, 18 Stirling Road. (908) 753-0190. Wayne Wycliffe Gordon, jazz trombonist, and his quintet. Feb. 25 at 4 p.m.; artist talk at 3 p.m. $8 to $15. Shea Center for Performing Arts, William Paterson University, 300 Pompton Road. (973) 720-2371. West Long Branch ''The Celtic Connection,'' Spanish and Irish dance. Feb. 24 at 8 p.m. $12 to $25. Cherish the Ladies, Irish music, with traditional step dancers. Feb. 25 at 7 p.m. $32. Pollak Theater, Monmouth University, 400 Cedar Avenue. (732) 571-3400. OUTDOORS Ringwood Maple sugaring festival, with demonstrations and bake sale. Feb. 25, noon to 4 p.m. $5. New Jersey Audubon Society's Weis Ecology Center, 150 Snake Den Road. (973) 835-2160. THEATER Atlantic Highlands ''Caught in the Net,'' comedy by Ray Cooney. Through Feb. 24. $15 and $20. First Avenue Playhouse, 123 First Avenue. (732) 291-7552. Ewing Township ''Private Lives,'' comedy by Noel Coward, presented by Shakespeare '70. Through Feb. 25. $6 and $12. Kendall Hall, College of New Jersey, 2000 Pennington Road. (609) 882-5979. Glassboro ''Seven Guitars,'' drama by August Wilson. Friday through March 4. $5 and $10. Tohill Theater, Rowan University. (856) 256-4545. Hackensack The Hackensack Theater and Playwright Festival: ''God is a Puerto Rican,'' by John Watts, with ''Healing'' and ''The Therapeutic Hour,'' both by Guy Fredrick Glass; and ''Behold a Pale Horse: The Life and Times of Chuck Pennell,'' by Edgar Munoz, with ''Lonely Hearts,'' by Mr. Watts. Wednesday through Feb. 24. $8. Hackensack Cultural Arts Center, 39 Broadway. (201) 646-8042. Hoboken ''Into the Woods,'' musical by James Lapine and Stephen Sondheim. Through Feb. 25. $15 to $25. DeBaun Auditorium, Edwin A. Stevens Hall, Stevens Institute of Technology, Fifth and Hudson Streets. (201) 216-8937. Long Branch ''tempOdyssey,'' comedy by Dan Dietz. Thursday through March 18. $25 to $40. New Jersey Repertory Company, 179 Broadway. (732) 229-3166. Madison ''Where the Sun Never Sets,'' comedy by Bob Clyman. Through Feb. 18. $15 to $35. Playwrights Theater of New Jersey, 33 Green Village Road. (973) 514-1787, Extension 30. Montclair ''Honor and The River,'' play by Anton Dudley. Through Feb. 25. $16 to $30. Luna Stage, 695 Bloomfield Avenue. (973) 744-3309. Morris Township ''Hot 'N Cole,'' a musical revue of the work of Cole Porter. Through Feb. 18. $15 to $35. Bickford Theater, 6 Normandy Heights Road. (973) 971-3706. Morristown ''Berenstain Bears on Stage,'' musical by Stan and Jan Berenstain; presented by the Omaha Theater Company. Feb. 25 at 1:30 and 4 p.m. $12. The Community Theater, 100 South Street. (973) 539-8008. New Brunswick ''Movin' Man,'' autobiographical one-man show by Glynn Turman. Friday through March 4. $40 to $55. Crossroads Theater, 7 Livingston Avenue. (732) 545-8100. New Brunswick ''Rain,'' by Cirque Éloize, circus. Friday through Feb. 25. $25 to $50. State Theater, 15 Livingston Avenue. (732) 246-7469. Newark ''Louie and Ophelia,'' drama by Gus Edwards. Through Feb. 18. $17. New Jersey Performing Arts Center, 1 Center Street. (888) 466-5722. Oradell ''The Mystery of Irma Vep,'' comedy by Charles Ludlam, presented by the Bergen County Players. Through March 10. $15 and $18. Little Firehouse Theater, 298 Kinderkamack Road. (201) 261-4200. Princeton ''The Brothers Size,'' drama by Tarell Alvin McCraney; staged readings of Mr. McCraney's other ''Brother/Sister Plays'' are also part of the McCarter's IN-Festival, through Feb. 18. $15. McCarter Theater Center, 91 University Place. (609) 258-2787. Ridgewood ''The Man Who Came to Dinner,'' comedy by George S. Kaufman and Moss Hart. Friday through March 4. $10. West Side Presbyterian Church, 6 South Monroe Street. (201) 652-1966, Extension 19. Trenton ''Suitcase Stories,'' one-act plays by Passage Theater's Stage One Playwrights Unit. Through Feb. 18. $10. Mill Hill Playhouse, Front and Montgomery Streets. (609) 392-0766. Wayne ''End of the World Button,'' play by S. W. Senek. Friday through March 3. $8 and $11. Hunziker Theater, William Paterson University, 300 Pompton Road. (973) 720-2371. West Orange ''Peter Pan,'' musical based on J. M. Barrie's story. Through Monday. $22 and $25. JCC Metro West Center for the Arts, Maurice Levin Theater, 760 Northfield Avenue. (973) 736-3200, Extension 253. West Windsor ''For the Glory: The Civil War Musical in Gettysburg,'' by Frank Wildhorn, Jack Murphy and Gregory Boyd; presented by Chang/Ferrara Productions. Through Feb. 18. $10 to $16. Kelsey Theater, West Windsor Campus, Mercer County Community College, 1200 Old Trenton Road. (609) 570-3333. West Windsor ''The Mysteries,'' series of medieval plays, presented by Mercer County Community College students. Through Feb. 24. $10 and $12. The Studio Theater, Mercer County Community College, 1200 Old Trenton Road. (609) 570-3324. MUSEUMS AND GALLERIES Asbury Park ''Winter and Other Seasonal Moments,'' photographs and paintings, group show. Through Feb. 25. Hours: Fridays through Sundays, 1 to 5 p.m. Apex Gallery, 611 Cookman Avenue. (732) 776-7746. Cape May ''Small Towns, Black Lives: African American Communities in New Jersey,'' photography by Wendel A. White. Through May 13. $1 and $2. Mid-Atlantic Center for the Arts, 1048 Washington Street. (609) 884-5404. Hamilton ''New Jersey Perspective,'' photographs by Owen Kanzler and sculpture by Kate Graves. Through April 8. $1 to $12; members free. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 10 a.m. to 8 p.m., April through October; 10 a.m. to 6 p.m., November through March. Grounds for Sculpture, 18 Fairgrounds Road. (609) 586-0616. Hopewell ''I Am a Tree,'' prints by Frank Magalhães. Through March 11. Hours: Saturdays and Sundays, noon to 5 p.m. Gallery 14, 14 Mercer Street. (609) 333-8511. Lincroft African-American Stamp Art from the collection of Wanda Garbett. Through Feb. 18. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 4:30 p.m.; Sundays, 1 to 5 p.m. Monmouth Museum, Brookdale Community College, Newman Springs Road. (732) 747-2266. Newark ''Landscape Revisited: Fact and Metaphor,'' group show. Through March 29. Hours: daily, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. City Without Walls, 6 Crawford Street. (973) 622-1188. Newark ''Portraits of Science Explorers by Mary Alice Copp.'' Through Sunday. $3 to $7; members, free. Hours: Wednesdays through Fridays, noon to 5 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. Newark Museum, 49 Washington Street. (973) 596-6550. Newark ''Night of the Khmer Rouge: Genocide and Justice in Cambodia,'' photographic documents, film and records. Through Thursday. Paul Robeson Campus Center, Rutgers University-Newark Campus, 350 Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Blvd. (973) 353-5300. Newton ''Contemporary Burmese Art,'' presented by ArtAsiaNYC. Through March 9. Hours: Mondays through Fridays, 8 a.m. to 8 p.m.; Saturdays, 8 to 11 a.m. Sussex County Community College Art Gallery, 1 College Hill Road. (973) 300-2329. Oceanville ''Emerging Artists Exhibition: Spinning Worlds,'' work by Paul Santoleri and Carla Falb. ''Surface Rhythms,'' work by Bennett Bean and Barbara Bullock. Both through April 22. Noyes Museum of Art, 733 Lily Lake Road. (609) 652-8848. Upper Montclair ''Modern Polish Masters,'' group show. Through Feb. 28. J. K. K. Fine Arts, 594 Valley Road. (973) 744-0111. West Long Branch ''Objects of Divine Hatred: Remix Version 1.0,'' mixed-media. Through March 16. ''Derek Boshier: Extreme Makeover,'' mixed-media. Through March 23. Hours: Mondays through Wednesdays and Fridays, 9 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Thursdays, 9 a.m. to 7 p.m. 800 and Ice House Galleries, Monmouth University, 400 Cedar Avenue. (732) 571-3512.
